{{About|the play|the 1989 film based on the play|Shirley Valentine (film)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Use British English|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox play | name = Shirley Valentine | image = Shirley Valentine.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = | writer = [[Willy Russell]] | genre = [[Comedy]]
[[Monodrama]] | setting = | subject = A holiday in Greece refreshes an unhappy middle aged Liverpool housewife in more ways than one | premiere = 1986 | place = [[Everyman Theatre, Liverpool|Everyman Theatre]]
[[Liverpool]] | orig_lang = English }} '''''Shirley Valentine''''' is a one-character play by [[Willy Russell]].{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=THEATER; One Woman's Fling In 'Shirley Valentine'|first=Alvin|last=Klein|date=24 April 1994|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/24/nyregion/theater-one-woman-s-fling-in-shirley-valentine.html}}{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Shirley Valentine (1989) Review/Film; Shirley Valentine Talks With Others|first=Caryn|last=James|date=30 August 1989|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=950DE7D61F3AF933A0575BC0A96F948260}} Taking the form of a [[monologue]] by a middle-aged, [[working class]] [[Liverpool]] [[housewife]], it focuses on her life before and after a transforming holiday abroad. ==Plot== Wondering what has happened to her youth and feeling stagnant and in a rut, Shirley finds herself regularly alone and talking to the wall while preparing an evening meal of egg and chips for her emotionally distant husband. When her best friend offers to pay for a trip-for-two to [[Greece]], she packs her bags, leaves a note on the cupboard door in the kitchen, and heads for a fortnight of rest and relaxation. In Greece, with just a little effort on her part, she rediscovers everything she had been missing about her existence in England. She finds so much happiness, in fact, that when the vacation is over she decides not to return, ditching her friend at the airport and going back to the hotel where she'd been staying to ask for a job and to live a newly self-confident life in which she is at last true to herself. ==Productions== Commissioned by the [[Everyman Theatre, Liverpool|Everyman Theatre]] in [[Liverpool]], the play premiered in 1986, with [[Noreen Kershaw]] directed by Glen Walford. Two years later it opened in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] at the [[Vaudeville Theatre]], with [[Pauline Collins]] directed by [[Simon Callow]]. After eight previews, the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production, with Collins again directed by Callow, opened on 16 February 1989 at the [[Booth Theatre]], where it ran for 324 performances. [[Ellen Burstyn]] replaced Collins later in the run, and [[Loretta Swit]] starred in a US national tour in 1995. From 26 March - 8 May 2010, as part of the Willy Russell season at the [[Menier Chocolate Factory]], [[Meera Syal]] played Shirley in the production's first London West End revival. A West End transfer of the [[Menier Chocolate Factory]] production ran at the [[Trafalgar Studios]] from 20 July - 30 October 2010. [[Meera Syal]] reprised her role as Shirley; this production was adapted and broadcast by BBC Radio Four in 2010 and 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00wmxw3|title=Willy Russell - Shirley Valentine, Saturday Drama - BBC Radio 4|website=BBC}} A 30th Anniversary Tour, starring [[Jodie Prenger]] ran in the UK from March 2017 to November 2017. Prenger was met with rave reviews. ==Awards and nominations== ; Awards * 1988 [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Comedy]] * 1988 [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress]] * 1989 [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Play]] * 1989 [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] for Best Actress * 1989 [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Play]] * 1989 [[Theatre World Award]] for Outstanding Broadway Debut ;Nominations * 1989 [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding New Play]] * 1989 [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Play]] * 1989 [[Tony Award for Best Play]] ==Film adaptation== Russell adapted his play for a [[Shirley Valentine (film)|1989 film]] version, directed by [[Lewis Gilbert]], with Collins again playing the title role. ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last= Russell |first= Willy |title= Shirley Valentine and One for the Road |location= Portsmouth, NH |publisher= Methuen |date= 1988 |isbn= 0-413-18950-3 }} ==See also== *[[How Stella Got Her Groove Back]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IBDB show|7957}} {{OlivierAward Comedy 1976–2000}} [[Category:1986 plays]] [[Category:Adultery in plays]] [[Category:British plays adapted into films]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:Comedy plays]] [[Category:Laurence Olivier Award-winning plays]] [[Category:Monodrama]] [[Category:Plays by Willy Russell]] [[Category:Plays for one performer]] [[Category:West End plays]]

{{Infobox event | title = <!-- Title to display, if other than page name --> | image = I caught Spider-Man's wedding.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Image that was featured on a special commemorative bag that Mets/Spider-Man fans received at the stadium.<ref name="dangerousminds">{{cite web|url=http://dangerousminds.net/comments/i_thee_web_spider-man_and_mary_jane_get_married_at_shea_stadium_1987|publisher=dangerousminds.net|title=‘I thee web’: Spider-Man and Mary Jane get married at Shea Stadium, 1987 | Dangerous Minds|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref> | native_name = | native_name_lang = | english_name = | time = | duration = | date = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{start and end dates|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | venue = Shea Stadium | location = Flushing Meadows–Corona Park, Queens, New York City | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also_known_as = | type = Publicity stunt, live performance | theme = | cause = | first_reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organisers = <!-- or |organizers= --> | filmed_by = | participants = | outcome = | publication_bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | blank_label = <!-- or |blank_data= --> | blank1_label = <!-- or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }} '''Spider-Man's wedding''' at [[Shea Stadium]] in 1987 was a [[publicity stunt]] and live performance adaptation of the comic book storyline "[[The Wedding! (comics)|The Wedding!]]" produced by [[Marvel Comics]]. The event was meant to advertise the special issue of ''[[The Amazing Spider-Man]]'' comic book, which went on sale the next Tuesday and took place at home plate in front of more than 45,000 fans just before the New York Mets play the Pittsburgh Pirates.<ref name=model>{{cite news|last=Gross|first=Michael|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/style/spider-man-to-wed-model.html|title=Spider-Man to Wed Model|date= June 2, 1987|publisher=[[New York Times]]}}</ref><ref name="gothamist">{{cite web|url=http://gothamist.com/2012/08/21/video_when_spider-man_and_mary_jane.php|publisher=gothamist.com|title=Video: When Spider-Man And Mary Jane Got Hitched At Shea Stadium: Gothamist|accessdate=2017-01-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171106043759/http://gothamist.com/2012/08/21/video_when_spider-man_and_mary_jane.php|archivedate=2017-11-06|df=}}</ref><ref name="sbnation">{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2012/3/23/2897287/when-spider-man-got-married-in-shea-stadium|publisher=[[SB Nation]]|title=When Spider-Man Got Married In Shea Stadium|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="oldtimefamilybaseball">{{cite web|url=http://oldtimefamilybaseball.com/post/19778514207/great-moments-in-mets-history-or-the-time|publisher=Old Time Family Baseball|title=Great Moments in Mets History or: The Time Spider-man Married Mary Jane at Shea Stadium|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="comicsalliance">{{cite web|url=http://comicsalliance.com/stan-lee-officiates-spider-man-and-mj-wedding-in-awesome-1987-fo/|website=comicsalliance.com|publisher=[[Comics Alliance]]|author=Nadel, Nick|title=Stan Lee Officiates Spider-Man and MJ Wedding In Awesome 1987 Footage|accessdate=2017-01-08|date=April 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name="yahoo">{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/blog/big_league_stew/post/VintageTube-Spider-Man-Shea-Stadium-and-Morgan?urn=mlb,84584|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|title=VintageTube: Spider-Man, Shea Stadium and Morgan Freeman|work= [[Big League Stew]]|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="google">{{cite book|title=The Marvel Comics Guide to New York City|author=Sanderson, P.|date=2007|publisher=Gallery Books|isbn=9781416531418|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u4PMIT0Rv7cC&pg=PA205|page=205|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=Marvel Graphic Novels and Related Publications: An Annotated Guide to Comics, Prose Novels, Children's Books, Articles, Criticism and Reference Works, 1965–2005|author=Weiner, R.G.|date=2008|publisher=McFarland, Incorporated Publishers|isbn=9780786451159|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=npIsZV7grboC&pg=PA81|page=81|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=Jet|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|issn=0021-5996|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=37EDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53|page=53|accessdate=2017-01-08|date=1987-06-22}}</ref><ref name="veryfinenearmint">{{cite web|url=http://veryfinenearmint.com/2010/07/06/spider-man-weds-mary-jane-at-shea-stadium-1987/|publisher=veryfinenearmint.com|title=Spider-Man weds Mary Jane at Shea Stadium, 1987 « Very Fine / Near Mint|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="screenrant">{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/spider-man-15-things-you-didnt-know-about-mary-jane-watson/?view=all|publisher=screenrant.com|title=Spider-Man: 15 Things You Didn’t Know About Mary Jane Watson|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
==Production==
Mary Jane Watson's dress was designed by [[Willi Smith]] and was his last project before his passing.<ref>[[George Gustines|Gustines, George Gene]]. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9407E3DA1F30F937A35756C0A96E9C8B63&scp=57&sq=george+gene+gustines&st=nyt "Style – Pow! Kerplow!! Boing!!!,"] ''[[New York Times Magazine]]'' (May 4, 2008).</ref><ref name=model/><ref name="jimshooter">{{cite web|url=http://jimshooter.com/2011/09/three-comic-book-weddings-or-holy.html/|publisher=jimshooter.com|title=Three Comic Book Weddings, or Holy Matrimony! – Part 1 – JimShooter.com|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="birthmoviesdeath">{{cite web|url=http://birthmoviesdeath.com/2012/08/16/the-time-spider-man-got-married-at-shea-stadium|author=Devin Faraci|publisher=birthmoviesdeath.com|title=The Time Spider-Man Got Married At Shea Stadium | Birth.Movies.Death.|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
==Event== The show follows the comic book story and has [[Stan Lee]] officiating it.<ref>http://www.cbr.com/15-of-marvels-greatest-publicity-stunts/</ref><ref>http://thechalkboardmag.com/mature-models-ageless-beauties-inspiration</ref>
==Reception== Andy L. Kubai of ''[[Looper (website)|Looper]]'' stated that he originally believed that Marvel held the ceremony at Shea Stadium because they couldn't afford something larger like Yankee Stadium but believed it made more sense after he learned that the character Peter Parker is a Mets fan.<ref>http://www.looper.com/67846/hidden-details-missed-spider-man-comics/</ref> Gary Smith of ''[[Comic Book Resources]]'' stated that he believed that the wedding at Shea Stadium was Marvel's third greatest publicity stunt energy and that Stan Lee's part was very appropriate.<ref>http://www.cbr.com/15-of-marvels-greatest-publicity-stunts/</ref>
==Cast and characters== *[[Mary Jane Watson]] - [[Tara Shannon]]<ref>http://thechalkboardmag.com/mature-models-ageless-beauties-inspiration</ref> *[[Spider-Man]]/Peter Parker *[[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]] *[[Captain America]] *[[Iceman (comics)|Ice-Man]] *[[Firestar (comics)|Fire-Star]] *[[Green Goblin]] *[[Dr. Doom]]
==See also== * [[Spider-Man Live!]] * [[Marvel Universe Live!]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.heroesinmycloset.com/2010/08/to-thee-i-web-part-i-idol-banter.html To Thee I Web, Part I: Idol Banter]

{{unreferenced|date=June 2018}} '''The Flow Skatepark''' is a world-famous{{cn|date=June 2018}} [[skatepark]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]], US, established July 6, 2001 by Shannon Turner and Craig Billingsley. At approximately {{convert|50000|sqft|m2}}, The Flow is one of the largest indoor skateparks in the nation. It was voted #1 skatepark in the [[United States]] by [[Fox Sports 2|Fuel TV]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
[[Image:TheFlow1.jpg|thumb|The Flow|200px|right|A section of The Flow]]
The Flow Skatepark closed April 28, 2013. == Contests ==
'''The Dirty East''' The Dirty is one of the largest Bmx Pro/Am Contests in the midwest. It's been around since 2001. The Flow Skatepark closed April 28, 2013.
'''Hellaween'''
'''The King of Rhythm'''

{{multiple issues| {{film IMDb refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{missing information|critical reception|date=August 2015}} }} {{Infobox film | name = The Lost World | image =The Lost World (1992 film).jpg | caption =DVD cover | director = [[Timothy Bond]] | producer = [[Harry Alan Towers]] | writer = [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] (novel)
[[Marion Fairfax]] (screenplay) | starring = [[John Rhys-Davies]]

[[Ian Yule]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1992}} | runtime = 99 minutes | country = United States | awards = | language = English | budget = }} '''''The Lost World''''' is a 1992 film, based on the [[The Lost World (Conan Doyle novel)| book of the same name]] by Sir [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]. The movie is set in [[Africa]] rather than the book's setting of [[South America]], and the character of [[Lord John Roxton]] has been replaced with a female character played by [[Tamara Gorski]].{{cite web|title=The Lost World|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104759/|website=IMDB}} It was followed by a sequel the same year, '''''[[Return to the Lost World]]''''', with the same director and main cast. == Plot == Set in 1912, the film opens on Edward Malone, a junior reporter looking for an adventurous assignment. Malone is sent to interview [[Professor Challenger]], an explorer and researcher who believes he is on the trail of the "lost world," a mysterious place in Central Africa. Challenger has a picture of a cliff and a strange beast resembling a [[pterodactyl]] that is his only evidence of the place. The British scientific community finds his claims laughable. After receiving funding from the family of Jenny Nielson, a wildlife photographer and the daughter of a rich American contributor to the sciences, the "scientific community" agrees to organise an exploratory expedition under the leadership of the antagonistic Professor Summerlee. Summerlee agrees to Malone and Nielson coming on the expedition, but refuses to allow Challenger to be part of the expedition. With obvious reluctance, Challenger gives Summerlee a "map" to be opened at a road-end village in Africa at a particular date and time. The expedition departs. A newsboy associate of Malone named Jim stows away on the trip. The expedition arrives in Africa where they are joined by a female guide named Malu and a Portuguese called Gomez. Summerlee opens the map from Challenger, finding it blank, at which point Challenger appears from nowhere leaving Summerlee no option but to accept his guidance on the exhibition. Under Challenger's guidance they find the cliff in the picture and reach the top, but Gomez (who turns out to be the brother of a Portuguese who was killed on Challenger's first journey here) strands them with no way back down. Exploring the Lost World to find another way home, the team finds dinosaurs, from a pair of [[Anatosaurus]] to a pterodactyl rookery. Jim, Malone, and Malu narrowly avoid being eaten by a dinosaur (presumably a Herrerasaurus), only to find that their camp was attacked and the rest of the team is gone. The three discover a gathering of native tribesmen (painted with symbolic skeletons) who regularly sacrifice humans off a cliff to the carnivorous dinosaurs. While the 'skeleton men' sacrifice a man to a ''Tyrannosaurus rex'', Malone distracts the tribe while the other explorers and captured natives escape, and they retreat to the safety of a second tribe nearby (who use clothes, not paint). During these events, Summerlee notes some oddities about the "ritual" vegetation necklaces that the sacrifices (themselves) were dressed in. The second tribe's members, through Malu's translation, tell the explorers about a time long ago when the shamans of their tribe convinced some to worship the carnivorous dinosaurs, splitting the tribe in two. Summerlee deduces that the vegetation necklaces placed on the sacrifices provided some necessary nutrient or immunisation to the dinosaurs which had protected these dinosaurs from the extinction that the rest of the dinosaurs suffered globally (this being a theory Summerlee had espoused previously). The expedition team uses their modern knowledge and research to benefit the tribe with irrigation and horticultural benefits, to produce the antidote to a prehistoric plague. The skeleton tribe's leader is killed, and the two tribes reunite. The chief shows the team a hidden cave that will lead them back to their world, and has them promise that they will come back if they are ever needed. Returning to the river, the team is ambushed by Gomez. Gomez is shot and wounded, but instead of killing him, Challenger leaves him behind, saying, "Let the jungle have him." Malu stays in Africa, and the others return home. The Royal Zoological Society in London rules that Challenger and Summerlee have insufficient evidence of their tale, until Jim reveals that he brought back a baby pterodactyl. The team is celebrated for their achievements, but when Malone, Jenny, and Jim discover the pterodactyl (named Percival), is unhappy being kept in a zoo, they release him, allowing him to fly back to the "lost world". ==Cast== {{Div col}} * [[John Rhys-Davies]] - as Professor ''George Edward Challenger'' * [[David Warner (actor)|David Warner]] - as Professor ''Summerlee'' * [[Eric McCormack]] -as ''Edward Malone'' * [[Nathania Stanford]] - as Guide ''Malu'' * [[Darren Peter Mercer]] - as ''Jim'' * [[Tamara Gorski]] - as ''Jenny Nielson'' * [[Sala Came]] - as ''Dan'' * [[Fidelis Cheza]] - as ''Chief Palala'' * [[John Chinosiyani]] - as Witch Doctor * [[Innocent Choda]] - as ''Pujo'' * Brian Cooper - as Policeman * Charles David - as ''Mojo Porter'' * [[Kate Egan]] - as ''Kate Crenshaw'' * [[Mike Grey]] - as ''Mojo Porter'' * [[Robert Haber]] - as ''Maple White'' * Geza Kovacs - as Portugese ''Gomez'' * [[Ian Yule]] - as ''Peterson'' {{Div col end}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{portal|Film|Dinos}} * {{IMDb title|0104759|The Lost World}} {{Harry Alan Towers}} {{The Lost World}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lost World (1992 film), the}} [[Category:1990s adventure films]] [[Category:1992 films]] [[Category:Professor Challenger films]] [[Category:Films set in 1912]] [[Category:Films set in Africa]] [[Category:1990s fantasy films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Fantasy adventure films]] [[Category:Dinosaur films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Films based on British novels]]
