revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox organization |name = The Magic Circle |image = Logo for The Magic Circle.jpg |image_border = |size = 300px |alt = Logo of the Society |caption = The Magic Circle Theatre |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = ''Indocilis Privata Loqui''
("not apt to disclose secrets") |formation = {{Start date and age|1905}} |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = To promote and advance the art of magic |headquarters = Euston
[[London]], {{postcode|NW|1}}
United Kingdom |coords = {{coord|51|31|35|N|0|08|08|W|display=inline,title|region:GB}} |membership = ~1,450 |language = English |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Scott Penrose]] |main_organ = The Magic Circular |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.themagiccircle.co.uk themagiccircle.co.uk] |remarks = }} '''The Magic Circle''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[organisation]], dedicated to promoting and advancing the art of [[magic (illusion)|magic]]. Applicants must qualify for membership, either through a performance exam or by a written thesis on a branch of magic, after which they will be designated Member of the Magic Circle (M.M.C.) Further distinctions may earn them the title Associate of the Inner Magic Circle (A.I.M.C.), and Member of The Inner Magic Circle (M.I.M.C) a select group limited to 300 members. The Circle was founded in 1905, and was male-only until 1991. There is a junior branch, the Young Magicians Club, which gained popularity through the success of the [[Harry Potter]] franchise. == History == [[File:Magic Circle Blue Plaque 2017.jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Blue plaque]] commemorating the founding of the Magic Circle on the former Pinoli's in [[Wardour Street]]]] [[File:Magic Circle staircase.jpg|thumb|upright|A staircase at the Magic Circle building]] The Magic Circle was founded in 1905 after a meeting of 23 amateur and professional magicians at London's Pinoli's Restaurant. At this founders meeting, chaired by [[Servais Le Roy]], those present decided upon the name of the Society: it was initially felt that the name of the Society should be the Martin Chapender Club, in memory of the performer and founding member who had recently died at the age of twenty-five. However, it was then agreed that the name "Magic Circle" would be more appropriate and that this name shared the same initials as those of Martin Chapender. The first official meeting was at the Green Man [[public house]] in [[Soho]], but meetings were later in a room at [[St. George's Hall (London)|St George's Hall]] in Langham Place, where [[David Devant]] and [[John Nevil Maskelyne]] were regularly seen performing.{{cite web |url=http://www.illusionist.co.uk/magician-blog/2010/06/magic-circle-magician-faq/ |title=Magic Circle Magician FAQ |first=Andi |last=Gladwin |authorlink=Andi Gladwin |date=June 2010 }} Devant became the first president of the Magic Circle, and in 1906, Maskelyne edited the first issue of ''The Magic Circular'' magazine, a regular feature for members ever since. The ''Magic Circular'' claims to be the longest-running regular magic magazine in conjuring history. The club was male-only until 1991, when more than 75% of members voted to admit women. As of 2010 there were around eighty female members of the Magic Circle, including [[Paul Daniels]]' wife, [[Debbie McGee]]. In 2014, [[Megan Knowles-Bacon]] became the first female officer in the Magic Circle, as well as the youngest person to be elected as an officer; she was elected as secretary.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/culturenews/11217461/Magic-Circle-elects-Megan-Knowles-Bacon-as-first-female-officer.html|title=Magic Circle elects Megan Knowles-Bacon as first female officer|date=7 November 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=7 November 2014}} == Motto == The motto of the society is the Latin ''indocilis privata loqui'', roughly translated as "not apt to disclose secrets" (lit. "incapable [of] speaking [of] private [things]") ; members give their word not to wilfully disclose magic secrets other than to bona fide students of magic. Anyone breaking this or any other rule may be expelled. == Headquarters == [[File:Houdini's cabinet.jpg|thumb|'[[Harry Houdini|Houdini']]s Cabinet' at The Magic Circle Museum, London]] Since 1998, the Magic Circle building{{cite web|url=http://venue.themagiccircle.co.uk/ |title=Welcome to The Magic Circle |publisher=The Magic Circle |accessdate=2014-07-22}} in central London near [[Euston Station]] in [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]] has been available for meetings and corporate entertainment. It was voted the UK's Number One Venue in the hospitality industry's Top 20 UK Venues poll 2008. The Magic Circle's headquarters houses a [[theatre]], library, museum, a dining room, a clubroom and bars. The museum features magic tricks, props, posters, programs, toys, photographs and artefacts related to conjuring history. Items of interest include, [[Robert Harbin]]’s original [[Zig Zag Girl|Zig Zag]] illusion, [[Chung Ling Soo]]'s robes, an original [[Sooty]] with associated [[Harry Corbett]] apparatus, sets of props used by television magicians [[David Nixon (magician)|David Nixon]] and [[Tommy Cooper]], items and a sound recording of [[Harry Houdini]] taken from an Edison cylinder, and a set of cups and balls used by HRH [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] when he took his Magic Circle exam in 1975{{Cite news|url=https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/prince-charles-performs-his-first-conjuring-trick-in-public-news-photo/888813084#/prince-charles-performs-his-first-conjuring-trick-in-public-to-gain-picture-id888813084|title=Prince Charles performs his first conjuring trick in public to gain his membership to the Magic Circle|work=Getty Images|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-GB}}. Visits are by arranged tour.{{cite web |url=http://londonist.com/2010/05/inside_the_magic_circle_of_london.php |title=Inside The Magic Circle Of London |work=[[Londonist]] |last1=Soteriou |first1=Helen |last2=Brown |first2=Matt |date=5 May 2010 |accessdate= 2010-01-22 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.themagiccircle.co.uk/about-the-club/ourmuseum |title=Our Museum |publisher=The Magic Circle |accessdate=2014-05-12}} == Membership == Magicians who wish to join may spend up to two years as an Apprentice before applying for full membership. They need to have known two current members for at least one year and must be at least 18 years old. These two members are then asked to act as sponsors, or referees, on the candidate's application form and propose them as a suitable candidate for membership. Following the receipt and processing of the application, the candidate is invited to an interview with the examinations secretary, usually at the London headquarters. If the candidate proves suitable and sufficiently knowledgeable a performance exam is scheduled or a thesis may be written. The exam takes place in front of a panel of judges, and candidates must demonstrate their skills to members in a rehearsed act.{{cite web|url=http://www.themagiccircle.co.uk/attachments/193_193_GuideFullRevised.pdf|title=The Magic Circle guide to examinations}} If a thesis is chosen, it is read by two examiners and a copy is made available in the Magic Circle library. The final stage is by vote by members of the Council, who will approve the candidate as a member. Once the applicant is successful, they are free to call themselves "Members of the Society" and use the letters '''''M.M.C.''''' after their name. Members of the Magic Circle include: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], [[Luis de Matos (magician)|Luis de Matos]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ionline.pt/artigos/mais/magico-luis-matos-premiado-londres-pelo-the-magic-circle|title=ionline|website=ionline|accessdate=22 March 2018}} [[Michael Vincent (magician)|Michael Vincent]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0c3qI4ijaP8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=Michael+Vincent&f=false|title=Circle Without End: The Magic Circle 1905-2005|first1=Edwin Alfred|last1=Dawes|first2=Michael|last2=Bailey|date=1 July 2005|publisher=Jeremy Mills Publishing|accessdate=22 March 2018|via=Google Books}} [[Dynamo (magician)|Dynamo]],{{cite web|url=http://themagiccircle.co.uk/news/716-dynamo-wins-best-entertainment-programme|title=Dynamo wins Best Entertainment Programme|website=themagiccircle.co.uk|accessdate=22 March 2018}} [[Tom London (magician)|Tom London]], {{cite web|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/ashford/news/americas-got-talent-star-surprises-129383/|accessdate=3 May 2018}} [[John Archer (magician)|John Archer]],{{cite web|url=http://www.examiner.co.uk/news/local-west-yorkshire-news/2009/06/10/huddersfield-magic-circle-to-celebrate-60th-anniversary-86081-23831071/|title=Huddersfield Magic Circle to celebrate 60th anniversary|date=10 June 2009|publisher=Huddersfield Daily Examiner}} [[:it:Walter Rolfo|Walter Rolfo]],{{cite web|url=http://www.torinotoday.it/eventi/walter-rolfo-magic-circle-londra.html|title=Il torinese Walter Rolfo nel club dei migliori maghi del mondo|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2018}} and [[Stephen Fry]]. Members may take a further examination to achieve the degree of '''''Associate of the Inner Magic Circle'''''. The designation '''A.I.M.C.''' shows this higher membership. The A.I.M.C. degree can also be attained through thesis, and in rare cases – that is when a candidate gains 18 or higher out of a possible 20 marks in the written exam – examinees taking the M.M.C. exam are awarded the A.I.M.C. degree. Those who attain an A.I.M.C. degree as a result of a performance examination are awarded the A.I.M.C. with silver star. Within the society, there are a number of members never exceeding three-hundred known as the "'''Inner Magic Circle'''". Full membership of the Inner Magic Circle is denoted by the letters '''M.I.M.C.''' after the member's name. '''Membership of the Inner Magic Circle''' is by call of The Society's President. The M.I.M.C. degree may be awarded with a gold star, to signify that the recipient is a performer of magic (as opposed to e.g. an inventor, historian or noteworthy volunteer for the Society). The honour of a gold star does not necessarily signify the holder's excellence as a performer and not all recipients are performers of excellence. Members must undertake not to reveal magic secrets to anyone except bona fide magicians, on pain of expulsion.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} == The Young Magicians Club == ''The Young Magicians Club''{{cite web |url=http://www.youngmagiciansclub.com/index.php/about-us |title=About Us |publisher=The Young Magicians Club |accessdate=2014-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108003320/http://www.youngmagiciansclub.com/index.php/about-us |archivedate=8 November 2014 |df=dmy-all }} is part of the ''Youth Initiative of the Magic Circle'' (the other major part being the prestigious ''Young Magician of the Year Competition'') and is a club for magicians between the inclusive ages of 10 and 18 which was founded in 1996. Sponsored by the Magic Circle, members of the Young Magicians Club meet for monthly workshops at the Magic Circle Headquarters, the 'Centre for the Magic Arts' in London.{{cite web |url=http://www.magicweek.co.uk/magic_articles/article_young_magicians.htm |title=The Young Magicians Club |last=Thomson |first=Ian A. |date=July 2000 |work=MagicWeek |accessdate=2013-01-02}} The Young Magicians Club has a current membership of around 200 members.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1367811/Harry-Potter-conjures-wave-of-Magic-Circle-applications.html |title=Harry Potter conjures wave of Magic Circle applications |accessdate=2008-07-19 |work=[[The Sunday Telegraph]] |date=27 August 2000 | location=London | first1=Sam | last1=Wallace | first2=Macer | last2=Hall}} The Young Magicians Club's principal means of communication among its members is its bi-monthly magazine ''Secrets''. The worldwide membership also communicates through a members-only on-line forum on the Young Magicians Club website. Membership in The Young Magicians Club requires no interview or exam and is open to all young people interested in magic. There are monthly all-day workshops for members who come from all over the country to take part. Adult members of the Magic Circle take on the responsibility of instructing the members of the Young Magicians Club. Local adult magic clubs will often have a junior magicians club attached to them but The Young Magicians Club is the only such club associated with the Magic Circle. Members of the Young Magicians Club are eligible to join the Magic Circle at a reduced rate when they reach 18, but then they must complete the examination procedure for full membership.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} The Young Magicians Club holds their annual one-day convention every October called 'J-Day'. The convention includes lectures and the finals of two competitions with awards, which include the ''Home Counties Trophy'' for stage magic, ''The Mark Leveridge Cup'' for close-up magic, ''Kaymar Komedy Cup'' and the ''Peter McCahon Award for Originality''. In recent years, the celebrity guest lectures have been presented by [[Derren Brown]] in 2010, [[Dynamo (magician)|Dynamo]] in 2011, [[John Archer (magician)|John Archer]] in 2012, [[Marvin Berglas]] in 2013, [[Luis de Matos (magician)|Luis De Matos]] in 2014 and Dave Loosley and [[Andi Gladwin]] in 2015. The popularity of the [[Harry Potter]] franchise was one of the key reasons for the organisation's growth this century with membership doubling after the announcement of the first film in 2001. ==See also== * [[American Museum of Magic]] * [[List of magic museums]] == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == * Tim Hulse, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/magicians-fight-to-make-each-other-vanish-1196378.html "Magicians fight to make each other vanish"], ''[[The Independent]]''. 6 September 1998. Retrieved 21 May 2015. * Sam Wallace and Macer Hall, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2000/08/27/npot27.xml "Harry Potter conjures wave of Magic Circle applications"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 19 June 2001. Retrieved 1 March 2008. * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/4341094.stm 'Now, is that magic?'], [[BBC News]], 14 October 2005. Retrieved 1 March 2008. * Simon O'Hagan, [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-103314091.html "Secret London: Tricks and treats, The Centre for the Magic Arts"], ''The Independent on Sunday'', 15 June 2003. Retrieved via subscription 1 March 2008. == External links == {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.themagiccircle.co.uk/ }} * [http://www.youngmagiciansclub.co.uk/ The Young Magicians Club website] {{Magic organizations}} {{Magic and Illusion}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Magic Circle, The}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in the London Borough of Camden]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in London]] [[Category:Magic museums]] [[Category:Magic organizations]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1905]] [[Category:Performing arts museums]] [[Category:Museums in the London Borough of Camden]] [[Category:Theatres in the London Borough of Camden]] [[Category:1905 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organisations based in the London Borough of Camden]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}}
''[[The New York Times]]'' has been the subject of criticism from a variety of sources. Criticism has been aimed at the newspaper has been in response to individual controversial reporters, along with alleged [[Media bias in the United States|political bias]].<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Daniel Okrent]] |title=Is The New York Times a Liberal Newspaper? |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E7D8173DF936A15754C0A9629C8B63 |quote= |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 25, 2004 |accessdate=September 28, 2014 }}</ref>
''The New York Times'' used to have a public editor who acted as an [[ombudsman]] and "investigates matters of journalistic integrity".<ref name="public">{{cite news |title=Margaret Sullivan |url=http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/09/24/shonda-rhimes-alessandra-stanley-margaret-sullivan-column/?module=BlogPost-Title&version=Blog%20Main&contentCollection=Opinion&action=Click&pgtype=Blogs&region=Body |quote=Margaret Sullivan is the fifth public editor appointed by The New York Times. ... The public editor’s office also handles questions and comments from readers and investigates matters of journalistic integrity. The public editor works independently, outside of the reporting and editing structure of the newspaper; her opinions are her own. |newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 24, 2014 |accessdate=September 28, 2014 }}</ref> The sixth and last NYT public editor was Liz Spayd, who contributed her last piece in June 2017.<ref name="LSpayd"> {{cite news |title= The Public Editor Signs Off |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/02/public-editor/liz-spayd-final-public-editor-column.html |quote= And who will be watching, on this subject or anything else, if they don’t acquit themselves well? At The Times, it won’t be the public editor. As announced on Wednesday, that position is being eliminated, making this my last column. Media pundits and many readers this week were questioning the decision to end this role, fearing that without it, no one will have the authority, insider perspective or ability to demand answers from top Times editors. There’s truth in that. But it overlooks a larger issue. |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 2, 2017 |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref>
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The New York Times'' controversies}} == Los Alamos investigation == In 1999, the ''Times'' ran a series of stories about alleged theft of classified documents from [[Los Alamos National Lab]] in [[New Mexico]].<ref>James Risen and Jeff Gerth (March 6, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/06/world/breach-los-alamos-special-report-china-stole-nuclear-secrets-for-bombs-us-aides.html "BREACH AT LOS ALAMOS: A special report; China Stole Nuclear Secrets For Bombs, U.S. Aides Say" (includes extensive corrections)], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>James Risen (March 16, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/16/world/los-alamos-scientist-admits-contacts-with-chinese-us-says.html "Los Alamos Scientist Admits Contacts With Chinese, U.S. Says"], ''The New York Times'' </ref><ref>James Risen (April 11, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/11/world/fbi-searches-home-of-researcher-fired-from-los-alamos.html " F.B.I. Searches Home of Researcher Fired From Los Alamos"], ''The New York Times'' </ref> The prime suspect, [[Taiwan]]-born U.S. citizen Dr. [[Wen Ho Lee]], had his name leaked to the ''Times'' by [[United States Department of Energy| U.S. Energy Department]] officials.<ref>James Risen (May 8, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/08/world/lawyer-issues-denial-for-los-alamos-scientist-suspected-of-spying-for-beijing.html "Lawyer Issues Denial for Los Alamos Scientist Suspected of Spying for Beijing"], ''The New York Times'' </ref><ref>James Risen (Aug. 7, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/07/world/security-issues-may-delay-los-alamos-case-us-says.html "Security Issues May Delay Los Alamos Case, U.S. Says"], ''The New York Times'' </ref><ref>James Risen (Sept. 11, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/11/us/los-alamos-punishes-3-for-role-in-spy-inquiry.html "Los Alamos Punishes 3 for Role in Spy Inquiry"], ''The New York Times'' </ref> Dr. Lee was indicted on 59 counts and jailed in [[solitary confinement]] for 278 days until he accepted a [[plea bargain]] from the government.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news| author=Bill Mears| title =Deal in Wen Ho Lee case may be imminent| publisher =[[CNN]]| date =May 22, 2006| url =http://www.cnn.com/2006/LAW/05/22/scotus.wenholee/| accessdate = 2008-11-07}}</ref><ref> [[Patsy T. Mink]], [[George Miller]], [[Nancy Pelosi]] (Oct. 12, 2000), [https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CRECB-2000-pt15/pdf/CRECB-2000-pt15-Pg22416.pdf 146 Cong. Rec. (Bound) 22416 - INVESTIGATION AND TREATMENT OF WEN HO LEE], U.S. House of Representatives proceedings in Congressional Record </ref> The alleged breach of security became a [[catalyst]] for the creation of the [[National Nuclear Security Administration]] (NNSA, not to be confused with the [[National Security Agency|NSA]] and the [[U.S. National Security Council|NSC]]). This was similar to how the [[9/11]] attacks led to the creation of the [[Department of Homeland Security]]. Dr. Lee was released after the government's case could not be proven.<ref>Jeffrey St. Clair; Alexander Cockburn (Jan. 5, 2018), [https://www.counterpunch.org/2018/01/05/james-risen-the-new-york-times-and-the-sliming-of-wen-ho-lee/ "James Risen, the New York Times and the Sliming of Wen Ho Lee"], ''CounterPunch'' </ref><ref>Wen Ho Lee; Helen Zia (2001), [https://www.writerswrite.com/books/excerpts/mycountryversusme.htm ''My Country Versus Me: The first-hand account by the Los Alamos scientist who was falsely accused of being a spy''], Hyperion, pp. 1–5</ref>
[[President Clinton]] issued a public apology to Dr. Lee over his treatment.<ref name="cnn"/> The [[United States federal judge|federal judge]] in charge of the case, [[James Aubrey Parker]], remarked that "top decision makers in the executive branch ... have embarrassed our entire nation and each of us who is a citizen."<ref>NYTimes (Sept. 14, 2000), [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/14/us/statement-by-judge-in-los-alamos-case-with-apology-for-abuse-of-power.html "Statement by Judge in Los Alamos Case, With Apology for Abuse of Power"], ''The New York Times'' </ref><ref>Jeremy Wu (March 12, 2018), [https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/revisiting-judge-parkers-apology-dr-wen-ho-lee-jeremy-wu "Revisiting Judge Parker’s Apology to Dr. Wen Ho Lee"], Linkedin </ref> Dr. Lee filed a lawsuit under the [[Privacy Act of 1974|Privacy Act]] alleging that officials had leaked false and incriminating information to the media before charges had been filed.<ref name="LeeZia2001">{{cite book|author1=Wen Ho Lee|author2=Helen Zia|title=My Country Versus Me: The first-hand account by the Los Alamos scientist who was falsely accused of being a spy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=79LaAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Richardson+had+leaked+my+name+to+James+Risen+of+the+New+York+Times%22|year=2001|publisher=Hyperion|isbn=978-0-7868-6803-2|page=320}}</ref> Dr. Lee's lawsuit was settled in 2006, just before the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] was set to decide whether to hear the case.<ref name="cnn"/> The issues were similar to those in the [[Plame affair criminal investigation]], when ''Times'' reporter [[Judith Miller]] spent 2½ months in jail rather than reveal her government source.<ref name="cnn"/>
==Anthrax attacks== On October 12, 2001, ''Times'' reporter [[Judith Miller]] became one of several victims of [[2001 anthrax attacks|alleged anthrax attacks]].<ref>David Barstow (Oct. 13, 2001), [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/13/nyregion/a-nation-challenged-the-incidents-anthrax-found-in-nbc-news-aide.html l "A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INCIDENTS; Anthrax Found in NBC News Aide"], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>Judith Miller (Oct. 14, 2001), [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/14/us/a-nation-challenged-the-letter-fear-hits-newsroom-in-a-cloud-of-powder.html "A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LETTER; Fear Hits Newsroom In a Cloud of Powder"], ''The New York Times''</ref> The book ''[[Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War]]'', which Miller had co-authored with two other ''Times'' staffers, had been published ten days earlier on October 2.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Judith Miller|author2=Stephen Engelberg|author3=William J. Broad|title=Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pSxF5IFIOoEC&q=Osama|date=October 2, 2001|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-0-684-87159-2}}</ref> It became a top [[New York Times Non-Fiction Bestsellers of 2001|''New York Times'' bestseller]] within a few weeks.<ref name="hawes">{{cite web|url=http://www.hawes.com/2001/2001-11-04.pdf|title=The New York Times Best Seller List|date=November 4, 2001|publisher=hawes.com|page=2|accessdate=2009-02-23}}</ref> Its cover art depicted a white envelope like those used in the anthrax incidents. The text, written before the [[September 11 attacks]], made reference to [[Islamic]] [[jihadists]]: {{cquote| Some of the more violent groups were underwritten by a wealthy [[Saudi]] exile, [[Osama bin Laden]], who hoped to spread his radical vision of Islamic rule to Muslims everywhere and drive the United States out of the Middle East and Africa.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Judith Miller|author2=Stephen Engelberg|author3=William J. Broad|title=Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pSxF5IFIOoEC&q=Osama|date=October 2, 2001|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-0-684-87159-2|page=138}}</ref>}} In 2002, ''Times'' columnist [[Nicholas Kristof]] wrote a series of columns<ref>Nicholas Kristof (Jan. 4, 2002), [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/04/opinion/profile-of-a-killer.html "Profile of a Killer"], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>Nicholas Kristof (May 24, 2002), [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/24/opinion/connecting-deadly-dots.html "Connecting Deadly Dots"], ''The New York Times'' </ref> indirectly suggesting that Dr. [[Steven Hatfill]], a former U.S. Army [[bioweapons|germ-warfare]] researcher named as a "[[person of interest]]" by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], might be a "likely culprit"<ref>Nicholas Kristof (July 2, 2002), [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/02/opinion/anthrax-the-fbi-yawns.html "Anthrax? The F.B.I. Yawns"], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>Nicholas Kristof (July 12, 2002), [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/12/opinion/the-anthrax-files.html "The Anthrax Files"], ''The New York Times''</ref> in the anthrax attacks.<ref>Nicholas Kristof (July 19, 2002), [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/19/opinion/case-of-the-missing-anthrax.html "Case of the Missing Anthrax"], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>Nicholas Kristof (Aug. 13, 2002), [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/13/opinion/the-anthrax-files.html "The Anthrax Files"], ''The New York Times''</ref> Dr. Hatfill was never charged with any crime. In 2004, Dr. Hatfill sued the ''Times'' and Kristof for [[libel]], claiming [[defamation]] and [[intentional infliction of emotional distress]].<ref name=suit>{{cite news |author=Jerry Markon |title=Former Army Scientist Sues New York Times, Columnist |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A47994-2004Jul13.html |journal=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 14, 2004 |accessdate=March 21, 2008}}</ref> After years of proceedings,<ref>[https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/791150/steven-j-hatfill-v-the-new-york-times-company-and-nicholas-kristof/ "Steven J. Hatfill v. The New York Times Company, and Nicholas Kristof, 416 F.3d 320"], CourtListener.com</ref> the case was dismissed in 2007, and the dismissal was upheld on appeal. In 2008, the case was appealed to the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] which refused to grant [[certiorari]], effectively leaving the dismissal in place. The basis for the dismissal was that Dr. Hatfill was a "public figure" and he had not proved malice on the part of the ''Times''.<ref>Kathleen Cullinan (Dec. 15, 2008), [https://www.rcfp.org/browse-media-law-resources/news/supreme-court-wont-hear-hatfills-libel-suit "Supreme Court won't hear Hatfill's libel suit"], Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press</ref>
==Jayson Blair affair== {{Main|Jayson Blair#Plagiarism and fabrication scandal}} In 2003, the ''Times'' admitted that [[Jayson Blair]], one of its reporters, had committed repeated [[Journalism scandals|journalistic fraud]] over a span of several years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/11/national/11PAPE.html?ei=5070&en=8dfc464a841fa742&ex=1159243200&pagewanted=print&position=|author1=Dan Barry |author2=David Barstow |author3=Jonathan D. Glater |author4=Adam Liptak |author5=Jacques Steinberg |title=Correcting the Record: Times Reporter Who Resigned Leaves Long Trail of Deception|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 13, 2003|accessdate = September 22, 2006}}</ref> The general professionalism of the paper was questioned, though Blair immediately resigned following the incident. Questions of [[affirmative action]] in journalism were also raised,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2082661/#blair|author=Kaus, Mickey|title="Affirmative retraction at the NYT" also titled "Keller in the Cellar?"|date=May 12, 2003|publisher=''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' online magazine|accessdate = September 24, 2006}}</ref><ref>Shafer, Jack, "The Jayson Blair Project How did he bamboozle the New York Times?" "Pressbox" column, ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' online magazine, May 8, 2003</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/18/opinion/18public.html?ei=5070&en=71d8d06f8322b11c&ex=1159243200&pagewanted=print|author=Calame, Byron|title="Preventing a Second Jason Blair" ("The Public Editor" column)|date=June 18, 2006|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate = September 22, 2006}}</ref> since Blair is [[African American|black]]. The paper's top two editors – [[Howell Raines]], the executive editor, and [[Gerald M. Boyd]], managing editor – resigned their posts following the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/Northeast/06/05/nytimes.resigns/|title=Top New York Times editors quit|author1=Arce, Rose |author2=Shannon Troetel |lastauthoramp=yes |date=March 1, 2004|accessdate=August 3, 2007 | work=CNN}}</ref>
==Judith Miller==
===Second Iraq War=== {{main|Judith Miller#The Iraq War}} Judith Miller wrote a series of exclusive and prominently displayed articles<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/ref/international/middleeast/20040526CRITIQUE.html|title=The ''Times'' and Iraq: A Sample of the Coverage|work=New York Times|accessdate=May 21, 2017}} "sampling of articles published by ''The Times'' about the decisions that led the United States into the war in Iraq, and especially the issue of Iraq's weapons"</ref> "strongly suggest[ing] Saddam Hussein already had or was acquiring an arsenal of [[weapons of mass destruction]]"<ref>Byron Calame (Oct. 23, 2005), [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/23/opinion/the-miller-mess-lingering-issues-among-the-answers.html "The Miller Mess: Lingering Issues Among the Answers"], ''The New York Times''</ref> using [[Ahmad Chalabi]] as her source prior to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. This aided the [[George W. Bush administration]] in making the case for war.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Franklin Foer]] |title=The Source of the Trouble |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/media/features/9226/ |quote=Pulitzer Prize winner Judith Miller’s series of exclusives about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, courtesy of the now-notorious Ahmad Chalabi—helped the ''New York Times'' keep up with the competition and the Bush administration bolster the case for war. |newspaper=[[New York magazine]] |accessdate=September 28, 2014 }}</ref><ref>NYTimes Editors (May 26, 2004), [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/26/world/from-the-editors-the-times-and-iraq.html "FROM THE EDITORS; The Times and Iraq"], ''The New York Times''</ref>
===Valerie Plame affair=== {{Main|Plame affair}} In October 2005, ''Times'' reporter [[Judith Miller (journalist)|Judith Miller]] was released from prison after 85 days, when she agreed to testify to [[special prosecutor]] [[Patrick Fitzgerald]]’s grand jury after receiving a personal waiver, both on the phone and in writing, of her earlier confidential source agreement with [[Lewis "Scooter" Libby]]. No other reporter whose testimony had been sought in the case had received such a direct and particularized release. Her incarceration has helped fuel an effort in Congress to enact a federal [[Shield laws in the United States|shield law]], comparable to the state shield laws which protect reporters in 31 of the 50 states. After her second appearance before the grand jury, Miller was released from her contempt of court finding. Miller resigned from the paper on November 9, 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://judithmiller.org/news/#76|author=Judith Miller|title=Judith Miller's Farewell|date=November 9, 2005|accessdate = November 4, 2006}}</ref>
==CampusJ== '''CampusJ Jewish Collegiate News''' was a website covering [[Judaism|Jewish]] news on college and university campuses with a network of student [[journalist]]s. In March 2005, CampusJ broke the story that ''[[The New York Times]]'' had negotiated a deal with [[Columbia University]] administrators to exclude student response in an article on [[academic bias]] in exchange for exclusive access to a report.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/98317/columbia-and-new-york-times-rachel-zabarkes-friedman|title=Columbia and The New York Times|work=National Review|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en}}</ref>
CampusJ, part of the [[J-Blogosphere]], was launched in February 2005 by [[Editing#Executive editor|editor]] and publisher [[Steven I. Weiss]] of ''Canonist''.<ref>[http://www.canonist.com Canonist website]</ref> The last posting was dated May 20, 2007. By 2008, the site appeared defunct, and many of the sections had no new content for months. CampusJ's staff of student reporters covered the Jewish news on thirty or more campuses, including [[American University]], [[George Washington University]], [[McGill University|McGill]], [[Northwestern University|Northwestern]], [[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] and [[Washington University in St. Louis|Washington University]], by reporting for campus-specific school homepages ([[blogs]]).
==National Security Agency revelations delayed== On December 16, 2005, a ''New York Times'' article revealed that the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]] had ordered the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) to intercept telephone conversations between suspected terrorists in the U.S. and those in other countries without first obtaining court warrants for the surveillance, apparently in violation of the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978]] (FISA) and without the knowledge or consent of the Congress. A federal judge recently held that the plan revealed by the ''Times'' was unconstitutional, and hearings have been held on this issue in Congress. The article noted that reporters and editors at the ''Times'' had known about the intelligence-gathering program for approximately a year but had, at the request of White House officials, delayed publication to conduct additional reporting. The Justice Department has launched an investigation to determine the sources of the classified information obtained by the ''Times''. The men who reported the stories, [[James Risen]] and [[Eric Lichtblau]], won the [[Pulitzer Prize]] for national reporting in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/year/2006/national-reporting/|author=Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism|title=2006 Pulitzer Prize Winners - NATIONAL REPORTING|publisher=''The Pulitzer Board''|date=2006|accessdate = November 4, 2006}}</ref>
Because of the lapse in reporting [[Edward Snowden]] decided not to supply the ''New York Times'' with his information, choosing to go to the ''Guardian'' and ''Washington Post'' instead.<ref>{{cite news |title=New York Times Editor: Losing Snowden Scoop 'Really Painful' |url=https://www.npr.org/2014/06/05/319233332/new-york-times-editor-losing-snowden-scoop-really-painful |quote=But Snowden already knew the one place he didn't trust: The New York Times. He went instead to reporters working for The Guardian and The Washington Post, each of which posted the first in a series of breathtaking revelations one year ago |work=[[National Public Radio]] |date=June 5, 2014 |accessdate=September 28, 2014 }}</ref>
==Terrorist Finance Tracking Program== ::[[Terrorist Finance Tracking Program#Controversy regarding The New York Times' decision to publish]] Much controversy was caused when, on June 23, 2006, The Times (along with the [[Wall Street Journal]]<ref>{{cite web | title = Bank Records Secretly Tapped | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/1065118181.html?dids=1065118181:1065118181&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&fmac=&date=Jun+23%2C+2006&author=&desc=Bank+Records+Secretly+Tapped | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 }}</ref> and the [[Los Angeles Times]]<ref>{{cite web | title = Los Angeles Times : Page Not Found | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-swift23jun23,0,6482687.story | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 }}</ref>) revealed the existence of the [[Terrorist Finance Tracking Program]], a [[CIA]]/[[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of Treasury]] scheme to access transactional database of the [[Brussels]]-based [[Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication]] ("[[SWIFT]]"). In September 2006, the Belgian government declared that the SWIFT dealings with U.S. government authorities were, in fact, a breach of Belgian and European privacy laws.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/29/world/europe/29swift.html |title=Belgians Say Banking Group Broke European Rules in Giving Data to U.S |author1=Dan Bilefsky |author2=Eric Lichtblau |lastauthoramp=yes |date=September 29, 2006 |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=September 26, 2008}}</ref>
==Iran== On December 22, 2006 at the request of the Bush Administration, the paper removed sections of an Op-Ed piece critical of the administration's policy towards [[Iran]] which contained publicly available information that Iran cooperated after the 9/11 attacks and offered to negotiate a diplomatic settlement in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=06/12/22/1447213|author=Democracy Now, Headlines|title=NYT Publishes White House-Redacted Op-Ed Critical of Iran Policy|date=December 22, 2006|publisher=''[[Democracy Now]]''|accessdate=December 22, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061224143543/http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=06%2F12%2F22%2F1447213|archivedate=December 24, 2006|df=}}</ref>
==MoveOn.org ad controversy== {{Main|MoveOn.org ad controversy}} On Monday, September 10, 2007, the ''Times'' ran a full-page advertisement for [[MoveOn.org]] questioning the integrity of General [[David Petraeus]], the commander of U.S. forces in Iraq, entitled "General Petraeus or General Betray Us?" The Times only charged [[MoveOn.org]], a liberal activist group, $65,000 for the advertisement that, according to public relations director Abbe Serphos, normally costs around $181,692, or roughly a 64% discount. Serphos declined to explain the discount.<ref>{{cite web|newspaper=[[New York Post]] | title = Times Gives Lefties A Hefty Discount For 'Betray Us' Ad | url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/09132007/news/nationalnews/times_gives_lefties_a_hefty_di.htm | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 }}</ref>
Times spokeswoman Catherine Mathis denied the rate charged indicated a political bias and said it was the paper's policy not to disclose the rate paid by any advertiser. "We do not distinguish the advertising rates based on the political content of the ad," Mathis told [[Reuters]]. "The advertising folks did not see the content of the ad before the rate was quoted," she said, adding that there were over 30 different categories of ads with varying rates. Mathis confirmed the open rate for an ad of that size and type was around $181,000. Among reasons for lower rates are advertisers buying in bulk or taking a standby rate, she said. "There are many instances when we have published opinion advertisements that run counter to the stance we take on our own editorial pages," she said.
[[Jeff Jarvis]], a journalism professor who blogs on media at buzzmachine.com, said the key question for the Times was could any other political or advocacy group get the same rate under the same circumstances. "The quandary the Times gets stuck in is they don't want to admit you can buy an ad for that rate, no matter who you are," Jarvis said, noting that with print advertising revenues in newspapers generally decline to offer big discounts.
On a more general note, Jarvis said U.S. papers should emulate their counterparts in Britain where, for example, ''[[The Guardian]]'' makes no effort to hide its liberal stance. "In the U.S., I would argue newspapers should be more transparent and open about the views taken ... and The (New York) Times is liberal," he said.<ref>{{cite news | author = [[Claudia Parsons]] | title = NY Times criticized for ad attacking top US general | publisher = [[Reuters]] | date = September 13, 2007 |quote= An ad criticizing the top U.S. general in Iraq raised charges on Thursday that The New York Times slashed its advertising rates for political reasons -- an accusation denied by the paper. | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/mediaNews/idUSN1337674820070913 | accessdate = September 13, 2007 }}</ref>
[[Advertising Age]] reported that "MoveOn bought its ad on a 'standby' basis, under which it can ask for a day and placement in the paper but doesn't get any guarantees." A subsequent full-page ad bought by [[2008 Republican presidential candidates|Republican presidential hopeful]] [[Rudy Giuliani]] to rebut MoveOn.org's original ad was purchased at the same standby rate. [http://adage.com/mediaworks/article?article_id=120480] MoveOn later paid ''The Times'' the full rate once the newspaper publicly acknowledged that "an advertising sales representative made a mistake."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/09/23/moveon-to-pay-full-times-ad-rate/ |title=MoveOn to Pay Full Times Ad Rate |author=Kate Phillips |date=September 23, 2007 |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=September 26, 2008}}</ref>
==Corporate-influence concerns== In their book ''[[Manufacturing Consent: The Political Economy of the Mass Media|Manufacturing Consent]]'', [[Edward S. Herman|Edward Herman]] and [[Noam Chomsky]] analyze a variety of major U.S. media outlets, with an emphasis on ''The Times''. They conclude that a bias exists which is neither [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] nor [[Conservatism|conservative]] in nature, but aligned towards the interests of [[Multinational corporations|corporate conglomerates]], which own most of these media outlets and also provide the majority of their advertising revenue. The authors explain that this bias functions in all sorts of ways:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thirdworldtraveler.com/Herman%20/Manufac_Consent_Prop_Model.html|title=Manufacturing Consent: A Propaganda Model: excerpted from the book|accessdate=March 20, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314235027/http://www.thirdworldtraveler.com/Herman%20/Manufac_Consent_Prop_Model.html|archivedate=March 14, 2007|df=}}</ref>
<blockquote>"...by selection of topics, by distribution of concerns, by emphasis and framing of issues, by filtering of information, by bounding of debate within certain limits. They determine, they select, they shape, they control, they restrict — in order to serve the interests of dominant, elite groups in the society."<ref name="Chomsky1992">{{cite web|url=http://www.chomsky.info/interviews/1992----02.htm|title=Excerpts from Manufacturing Consent: Noam Chomsky interviewed by various interviewers|accessdate=2006-07-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721164116/http://www.chomsky.info/interviews/1992----02.htm|archivedate=2006-07-21|df=}}</ref></blockquote>
Chomsky and Herman also touch on the specific importance this perceived bias has in ''The Times'', saying: <blockquote>"...history is what appears in ''The New York Times'' archives; the place where people will go to find out what happened is ''The New York Times''. Therefore it's extremely important if history is going to be shaped in an appropriate way, that certain things appear, certain things not appear, certain questions be asked, other questions be ignored, and that issues be framed in a particular fashion."<ref name="Chomsky1992"/></blockquote>
==Duke University lacrosse case reporting== {{Main|2006 Duke University lacrosse case}} In their 2007 book ''Until Proven Innocent: Political Correctness and the Shameful Injustice of the Duke Lacrosse Case'', [[KC Johnson]] and [[Stuart Taylor, Jr.]] sharply criticize The New York Times for their editorial judgment and its effect on the case investigation. It claims that the original reports by Joe Drape tended to exonerate the accused players, which contradicted Times' editorial stance. This led to Drape's quick dismissal and replacement by Duff Wilson who took a pro prosecution stance.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.newsbusters.org/blogs/clay-waters/2007/09/19/new-book-destroys-credibility-nyts-duke-lacrosse-rape-coverage |title=New Book Destroys Credibility of NYT's Duke Lacrosse 'Rape' Coverage |author=Clay Waters |date=September 19, 2007 |publisher=newsbusters.org |accessdate=September 26, 2008}}</ref>
Also covering the case, sports writer Selena Roberts, made assertions, that "Something happened March 13." Furthermore, Roberts writes, “Players have been forced to give up their DNA, but to the dismay of investigators, none have come forward to reveal an eyewitness account.” Johnson points out that this statement was not true.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} The captains’ March 28, 2006 statement or examined the defense attorneys’ subsequent press conference both described the captains’ cooperation with police, occurred before she penned her column. The Times never ran a correction.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} Later Roberts in an interview in the Big Lead said, "I wrote that a crime didn’t have to occur for us to inspect the irrefutable evidence of misogyny and race baiting that went on that night."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thebiglead.com/?p=5024# |title=Archived copy |access-date=October 8, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210055311/http://thebiglead.com/?p=5024# |archive-date=December 10, 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Daniel Okrent]], former Times ombudsman admitted to the bias in the Times coverage of the case. He said, "It was too delicious a story. It conformed too well to too many preconceived notions of too many in the press: white over black, rich over poor, athletes over non-athletes, men over women, educated over non-educated. Wow. That's a package of sins that really fit the preconceptions of a lot of us."<ref>http://ajr.org/Article.asp?id=4379</ref>
==John McCain-lobbyist article criticism== {{See also|John McCain lobbyist controversy, February 2008}}
The February 21, 2008 ''The New York Times'' published an article on [[John McCain]]'s alleged relationship with lobbyist [[Vicki Iseman]] and other involvement with special interest groups.<ref>{{cite news | title = For McCain, Self-Confidence on Ethics Poses Its Own Risk - New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/21/us/politics/21mccain.html | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 | work=The New York Times | first1=Jim | last1=Rutenberg | first2=Marilyn W. | last2=Thompson | first3=David D. | last3=Kirkpatrick | first4=Stephen | last4=Labaton}}</ref> The article received a widespread criticism among both liberals and conservatives, McCain supporters and non-supporters as well as [[talk radio]] personalities. [[Robert S. Bennett]], whom McCain had hired to represent him in this matter, defended McCain's character. Bennett, who was the special investigator during the [[Keating Five]] scandal that ''The Times'' revisited in the article, said that he fully investigated McCain back then and suggested to the [[Senate Ethics Committee]] to not pursue charges against McCain.
<blockquote>"And if there is one thing I am absolutely confident of, it is John McCain is an honest and honest man. I recommended to the Senate Ethics Committee that he be cut out of the case, that there was no evidence against him, and I think for the New York Times to dig this up just shows that Senator McCain's public statement about this is correct. It's a smear job. I'm sorry. "<ref>{{cite web | title = Bob Bennett Reacts to New York Times Story on John McCain | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,331651,00.html| accessdate = 2008-02-25 | date = 2008-02-21 |publisher = Fox News Channell |author1=Sean Hannity |author2=Alan Colmes |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref> </blockquote>
Former staffer to President [[Bill Clinton]] and [[Hillary Clinton]] campaigner [[Lanny Davis]] said the article "had no merit." Stating that he did not support McCain's bid for the White House, Davis, who had himself lobbied for the same cause Iseman lobbied McCain for, said that McCain only wrote a letter to the FCC to ask them to "act soon" and refused to write a letter that supported the sale of the television station the article talked about.<ref>{{cite news | title = McCain disputes report of lobbyist relationship | url=http://washingtontimes.com/article/20080222/NATION/813344605/1002| accessdate = February 25, 2008 | date = February 22, 2008 |publisher = The Washington Times|author1=Ralph Z. Hallow |author2=Jennifer Harper |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref> Journalistic observers also criticized the article, albeit in a milder language. [[Tom Rosenstiel]], the director of the [[Project for Excellence in Journalism]], suggested that the article does not make clear the nature of McCain's alleged "inappropriate" behavior: "The phrasing is just too vague."<ref>{{cite web | title = Sign Up | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-media22feb22,1,2442135.story?page=2&cset=true&ctrack=8 | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 }}</ref> The article was later criticized by the [[White House]]<ref>{{cite web | title=White House Accuses NYT of Anti-GOP Bias | url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5iG-8I87S5w4QP8CPIrx2wh8irqmgD8UVVVBO0 | work=[[Associated Press]] | accessdate=February 24, 2008 | date=2008 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and by several news organizations including the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' editorial board.<ref>{{cite web | title = Follow the innuendo | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/02/23/EDGOV6TOM.DTL | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 }}</ref> Commentator [[Bill O'Reilly (commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] raised the question about why the paper had endorsed McCain on January 25, 2008 for the Republican nomination if they had information that alleged an inappropriate relationship.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,331867,00.html | title = Did The New York Times Smear John McCain? | date = February 22, 2008 | author = Bill O'Reilly | publisher = Fox News Channel}}</ref> The ''[[The Boston Globe|Boston Globe]]'', owned by the ''Times'', declined to publish the story, choosing instead to run a version of the same story written by the competing Washington Post staff. That version focused almost exclusively on the pervasive presence of lobbyists in McCain's campaign and did not mention the sexual relationship that the Times article hinted at.<ref>{{cite web | title = Top of the Ticket : Los Angeles Times : Boston Globe declines to publish parent paper's McCain story | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2008/02/maybe.html | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 }}</ref>
In response to the criticism, the ''Times'' editor [[Bill Keller]] was "surprised by the volume" and "by how lopsided the opinion was against our decision [to publish the article]".<ref>{{cite news | title = Howard Kurtz - N.Y. Times' Editor Bill Keller Responds to McCain Flap - washingtonpost.com | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/blog/2008/02/22/BL2008022201858.html | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> The diverse sentiments by the readers were summarized in a separate article by [[Clark Hoyt]], the ''Times'' [[public editor]], who concluded: "I think it is wrong to report the suppositions or concerns of anonymous aides about whether the boss is getting into the wrong bed."<ref>{{cite news | title = What That McCain Article Didn’t Say | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/24/opinion/24pubed.html?hp | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | date = 2008 | work=The New York Times | first=Clark | last=Hoyt}}</ref>
In September 2008, a McCain senior aide ([[Steve Schmidt]]) charged: "Whatever The New York Times once was, it is today not by any standard a journalistic organization. It is a pro-Obama advocacy organization that every day impugns the McCain campaign, attacks Sen. McCain, attacks Gov. Palin. ... Everything that is read in The New York Times that attacks this campaign should be evaluated by the American people from that perspective."
In December 2008, Iseman filed a sued ''The New York Times'', alleging that the paper had defamed her by, in her view, falsely implying that she had an illicit romantic relationship with McCain.<ref>{{cite news |first1=Paul |last1=Fletcher |first2=Alan |last2=Cooper |title=Lobbyist Vicki Iseman files $27M suit against New York Times |url=http://www.valawyersweekly.com/weeklyedition/2008/12/30/lobbyist-vicki-iseman-files-27m-suit-against-new-york-times/ |work=[[Virginia Lawyers Weekly]] |date=December 30, 2008 |accessdate=December 31, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105043018/http://www.valawyersweekly.com/weeklyedition/2008/12/30/lobbyist-vicki-iseman-files-27m-suit-against-new-york-times/# |archive-date=January 5, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In February 2009, the suit "was settled without payment and ''The Times'' did not retract the article."<ref name="LibelSuit">[[Richard Pérez-Peña]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/20/business/media/20lawsuit.html Libel Suit Against The Times Ends], ''New York Times'' (February 19, 2009).</ref> Unusually, however, ''The Times'' agreed to publish a statement from Iseman's lawyers on the ''Times'' website.<ref name="LibelSuit"/>
==Alessandra Stanley errors== [[Alessandra Stanley]] is a [[television]] critic. Complaints have been raised regarding the accuracy of her reporting.<ref name=lat/><ref name=hoyt/><ref name=gawk/><ref name=cjr/> Her tribute to [[Walter Cronkite]] on July 18, 2009 had eight factual errors.<ref name=gawk>{{cite news |title=Alessandra Stanley Corrected Hard |url=http://gawker.com/5320262/alessandra-stanley-corrected-hard |quote=There are corrections and then there are Corrections, and error-prone New York Times mistaker Alessandra Stanley got corrected today. For the second time. For the same Walter Cronkite story. |work=[[Gawker.com]] |accessdate=December 29, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=cjr/><ref name=signature>{{cite news |author=Alessandra Stanley |title=Cronkite’s Signature: Approachable Authority (correction appended)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/18/arts/television/18appraisal.html |quote= An appraisal on Saturday about Walter Cronkite’s career included a number of errors. In some copies, it misstated ...|work=The New York Times |date=July 17, 2009 |accessdate=December 29, 2009 }}</ref> Clark Hoyt, the [[public editor]] of ''The New York Times'' described Stanley as "much admired by editors for the intellectual heft of her coverage of television" but "with a history of errors".<ref name=lat>{{cite news |author=[[James Rainey]] |title=Cronkite blunder a revealing look inside New York Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-onthemedia5-2009aug05,0,5998442.column |quote=Wasn't the public fascinated, after all, to learn that Stanley and the nation's Paper of Record managed eight mistakes in an almost 1,200-word tribute to Uncle Walter? |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 5, 2009 |accessdate=August 6, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=hoyt>{{cite news |author=Clark Hoyt |title=How Did This Happen? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/02/opinion/02pubed.html |quote=The Times published an especially embarrassing correction on July 22, fixing seven errors in a single article — an appraisal of Walter Cronkite, the CBS anchorman famed for his meticulous reporting. The newspaper had wrong dates for historic events; gave incorrect information about Cronkite’s work, his colleagues and his program’s ratings; misstated the name of a news agency, and misspelled the name of a satellite. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=August 1, 2009 |accessdate=August 6, 2009 }}</ref> The New York Times printed a correction: <blockquote> An appraisal on Saturday about Walter Cronkite’s career included a number of errors. In some copies, it misstated the date that the Rev. Dr. [[Martin Luther King]] Jr. was killed and referred incorrectly to Mr. Cronkite’s coverage of D-Day. Dr. King was killed on April 4, 1968, not April 30. Mr. Cronkite covered the D-Day landing from a warplane; he did not storm the beaches. In addition, [[Neil Armstrong]] set foot on the moon on July 20, 1969, not July 26. “[[The CBS Evening News]]” overtook “[[The Huntley-Brinkley Report]]” on NBC in the ratings during the 1967-68 television season, not after Chet Huntley retired in 1970. A communications satellite used to relay correspondents’ reports from around the world was [[Telstar]], not Telestar. [[Howard K. Smith]] was not one of the CBS correspondents Mr. Cronkite would turn to for reports from the field after he became anchor of “[[The CBS Evening News]]” in 1962; he left CBS before Mr. Cronkite was the anchor. Because of an editing error, the appraisal also misstated the name of the news agency for which Mr. Cronkite was Moscow bureau chief after [[World War II]]. At that time it was [[United Press]], not [[United Press International]].<ref name=signature/> </blockquote>
An earlier contentious wording was on September 5, 2005 in an article on [[Hurricane Katrina]] where she wrote "Fox's Geraldo Rivera did his rivals one better: yesterday, he nudged an Air Force rescue worker out of the way so his camera crew could tape him as he helped lift an older woman in a wheelchair to safety." The Times later acknowledged that no nudge was visible on the broadcast tape.<ref name=cjr>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjr.org/regret_the_error/wrong_wrong_wrong_wrong_wrong.php |title=Wrong, Wrong, Wrong, Wrong, Wrong, Wrong |accessdate=July 27, 2009 |author=[[Craig Silverman]] |date=July 24, 2009 |work=[[Columbia Journalism Review]] |quote=In fairness, I’ll emphasize that the story’s seventh mistake was the result of an editing error. But six errors in a story she had ample time to work on and check is not acceptable, especially for a reporter with such a troubling history of error. ... |publisher=[[Columbia University]] }}</ref><ref name=nudge>{{cite news |author=Alessandra Stanley |title=Reporters Turn From Deference to Outrage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/05/national/nationalspecial/05watch.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 5, 2005 |accessdate=December 29, 2009 }}</ref>
==Story about fathers== In 2017, the ''New York Times'' was criticized for an article, headlined "How Vital Are Women? This Town Found Out as They Left to March," about fathers from [[Montclair, New Jersey]] who looked after their children while their wives participated in the [[2017 Women's March|Women's March]]. To some, the article "seemed to reinforce three old-fashioned tropes about gender and parenting: Men can’t handle parenting tasks; men who manage to handle the basics of parenting are exceptional and worthy of a news story; and parenting is fundamentally the work of women."<ref name="Peck">{{cite news |last=Peck|first=Emily |date= January 23, 2017 |title=New York Times Apologizes For Much-Ridiculed Story About Fathers |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/ny-times-fathers-womens-march_us_5886346be4b0e3a7356a7295 |newspaper=The Huffington Post |location= |access-date= }}</ref> The freelance writer who wrote the story apologized, and the Metro section editor stated: "It was a bad idea from the get-go. It was conceived with the best intentions, but it fell flat. And I regret it."<ref name="Peck"/>
==China== Quotation symbols were put around "terrorist" by the New York Times when describing the [[2014 Kunming attack]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Sheehan |first=Matt |date= March 3, 2014 |title=Chinese Netizens Lash Out At U.S. For Downplaying Severity Of Deadly Knife Attack |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/03/china-knife-attack_n_4887500.html |newspaper=The Huffington Post |location= |access-date= }}</ref>
Outdated figures about the carbon output of China were used by the New York Times in a 2015 article.<ref>{{cite news |last=West|first=James |date=November 4, 2015 |title=Sorry, New York Times: Your Big China Story is "Old News." |url=https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2015/11/sorry-new-york-times-your-big-china-story-old-news |newspaper=Mother Jones |location= |access-date= }}</ref>
==India== {{See Also|Anti-Indian sentiment#New York Times}} The newspaper's coverage of India has been heavily criticized by [[Sumit Ganguly]], a professor of [[political science]], for its "hectoring" and "patronizing" tone towards India. He finds anti-India bias in coverage of the [[Kashmir Conflict]], the [[Hyde Act]] and other India-related matters.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/2009/07/21/new-york-times-india-clinton-climate-nuclear-opinions-contributors-sumit-ganguly.html Hillary, India And 'The New York Times'], [[Sumit Ganguly]], [[Forbes]] Magazine</ref> Similar charges of racism against Indians have been levelled at the ''[[Huffington Post]].<ref> *{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/vamsee-juluri/indophobia-the-real-eleph_b_415237.html|title=Indophobia: The Real Elephant in the Living Room|work=The Huffington Post}} *{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/vamsee-juluri/nose-deep-in-their-own-pr_b_5601260.html|title=Nose Deep in Their Own... Prejudice: Hinduism and The New York Times' Sewage Problem|last=Vamsee Juluri USF professor; author|first='Rearming Hinduism: Nature|date=July 21, 2014|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=June 23, 2016}}</ref>''
United States lawmaker [[Kumar P. Barve]] described a recent editorial on India as full of "blatant and unprofessional factual errors or omissions" and having a "haughty, condescending, arrogant and patronizing" tone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/indianamerican-lawmaker-blasts-nyt-for-antiindia-editorial/492140/|title=Indian-American lawmaker blasts NYT for anti-India editorial|date=July 21, 2009|publisher=The Indian Express Limited|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=June 18, 2012}}</ref> In September 2014, The New York Times published a cartoon showing a [[Stereotypes of South Asians|stereotypical Indian]] turban-wearing man with a cow knocking at the door of an "elite space club". This was their response to recent accomplishments by the [[Indian Space Research Organization]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/29/opinion/heng-indias-budget-mission-to-mars.html|title=India’s Budget Mission to Mars|date=September 28, 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=July 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2778703/New-York-Times-slammed-racist-cartoon-India-s-Mars-mission.html|title=New York Times slammed for 'racist' cartoon about India's Mars mission|access-date=July 26, 2016}}</ref>. The cartoon "drew immediate criticism for being racist in content, and for engaging in classist and racist stereotyping".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sharanya-haridas/the-new-york-times-publis_b_5903118.html|title=The 'New York Times' Publishes Racist Comic About India's Space Mission|last=Writer|first=Sharanya Haridas|last2=Mumbai-raised|first2=Journalist|date=September 30, 2014|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=July 26, 2016|last3=dream|first3=Manhattan-residing Accidental Author-Publisher-Entrepreneur I. am Guy Kawasaki's}}</ref>
The New York Times has also opposed India's entry into the [[Nuclear Suppliers Group]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/05/opinion/sunday/no-exceptions-for-a-nuclear-india.html|title=No Exceptions for a Nuclear India|last=The Editorial Board|date=June 4, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref> while the US administration led by President [[Barack Obama]] was actively supporting India's membership.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-36476504|title=President Obama backs Indian entry to nuclear technology – BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref> This view was criticized for [[Indophobic]] bias by several western and Indian experts on nuclear issues.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thewire.in/41709/there-is-nothing-surprising-about-the-new-york-times-editorial-on-india-and-the-nsg/|title=The New York Times's Bias Should Not Surprise Us Anymore – The Wire|last=Thakur|first=Ramesh|date=June 9, 2016|website=The Wire|language=en-GB|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/asia/2016/06/06/india-global-governance-and-the-nuclear-suppliers-group/|title=Asia Unbound » India, Global Governance, and the Nuclear Suppliers Group|language=en-US|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref> The New York Times has also published editorials attacking traditional Indian dress as a "conspiracy by Hindu Nationalists",<ref>{{cite news |last= Qadri|first= Asgar|date= November 12, 2017|title= In India, Fashion Has Become a Nationalist Cause|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/12/fashion/india-nationalism-sari.html?_r=0}}</ref> which was widely criticized for ignorance<ref>{{cite news |last= Surendran|first= Vivek|date= November 14, 2017|title= Indian Twitter users roast New York Times for sari state of affairs|url= http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/new-york-times-sari-narendra-modi-bjp-fashion-nationalist-cause/1/1089062.html}} </ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Dutt |first= Barkha |date= November 17, 2017 |title= The New York Times tried to explain sari fashion — and became the laughingstock of India |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/global-opinions/wp/2017/11/17/the-new-york-times-tried-to-explain-sari-fashion-and-became-the-laughingstock-of-india/ }}</ref> and for promoting [[Orientalism]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Gautam |first= Nishtha|title= Back Off NYT, I’m a Sari & I’m Not a Tool in the Hands of Hindutva |url=https://www.thequint.com/voices/opinion/my-name-is-sari-and-im-not-a-tool-in-the-hands-of-hindutva}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Kaur|first= Nehmat|date= November 15, 2017 |title= The Sari Has Never Been About a ‘Hindu’ Identity |url=https://thewire.in/197262/sari-hindi-new-york-times/}}</ref>
== Yorkshire == In 2018 the New York Times came under criticism, including from the tourist office of the city of [[York]], for describing [[Yorkshire pudding]] as a "large, fluffy pancake" and recommending it be served with "syrup, preserves, confectioners' sugar or cinnamon sugar". A presenter for the BBC stated that the Yorkshire pudding's history was longer than that of the USA.<ref>{{cite news|title=New York Times thinks Yorkshire pudding is a dessert|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-44123786|date=May 15, 2018|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=May 15, 2018}}</ref>
==Publishing leaked photos from the Manchester bombing== On May 24, 2017, ''The New York Times'' caused outrage among the British police and government when it published leaked photos showing the scene of the [[2017 Manchester Arena bombing]]. Counter terror police chiefs said the leak undermined their investigation and victims' and witnesses' confidence. ''The New York Times'' published photos it says were gathered by UK authorities at the scene of the attack, including the remnants of a backpack, nuts and screws, and a device identified as a "possible detonator". [[Greater Manchester Police]] were said to be "furious" and said they would stop sharing information with the US. [[Presidency of Donald Trump|President Donald Trump]] the next day in a [[NATO]] summit condemned the media leaks, calling it "deeply troubling" and a "grave threat to our national security". ''The New York Times'' defended its decision to publish the photos, saying they were "neither graphic nor disrespectful of victims".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40048565|title=Manchester attack: Trump condemns media leaks|date=May 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40038630|title=Manchester attack: 'Fury' at US 'evidence' photos leak|date=May 25, 2017}}</ref>
== Abu Huzaifa al-Kanadi == Caliphate, a podcast for the New York Times, has received numerous criticism after [[Abu Huzaifa al-Kanadi]] admitted on the podcast that he “murdered people” while he was fighting for the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] group.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Buller|first1=Alice|title=New York Times podcast ‘Caliphate’ faces backlash over ethics|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1315651/media|newspaper=[[Arab News]]|date=June 5, 2018}}</ref> Numerous conservatives called for action against him after his statement, including [[Candice Bergen (politician)|Candice Bergen]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Conservative MPs call for action on self-described terror recruit for Daesh reportedly in Toronto|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/05/11/conservative-mps-call-for-action-on-self-described-terror-recruit-for-daesh-reportedly-in-toronto.html|publisher=[[The Canadian Press]]|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=May 11, 2018}}</ref> She criticized the liberal government after not ordering law enforcement against him. Bergen also called for Public Safety Minister [[Ralph Goodale]] to reveal whether the government knows where he is or not, but Goodale stated that it was the “opposition of keeping Canadians safe”.<ref>{{Cite news|last1= Khandaker|first1=Tamara|title= Politicians are freaking out over a podcast about returned Canadian ISIS fighter|url=|publisher=[[Vice News]]|date=May 11, 2018}}</ref> Huzaifa also received concerns from television journalist [[Diana Swain]] that he may be “lying” to [[The New York Times]] or [[CBC News]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Swain|first1=Diana|title=Did former Canadian ISIS member lie to the New York Times or to CBC News?|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/isis-abu-huzaifa-investigators-1.4669769|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=May 19, 2018}}</ref>
==Accusation of homophobia== After the ''Times'' tweeted a cartoon portraying Trump and Putin as a gay lovers, [[LGBT]] activist and Democratic Rep. [[Brian Sims]] said it's time to stop the [[homophobic]] jokes.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-44859358 'Homophobic' jokes about Trump and Putin criticised by LGBT campaigners]. BBC News. July 17, 2018.</ref> American transgender activist [[Jeffrey Marsh]] said "to have a group that's as well-established as The New York Times personally attacking you feels horrendous."<ref name="reuters"/>
A spokesperson for ''The Times'' defended the animation.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news |title=New York Times under fire for 'homophobic' cartoon of Trump and Putin |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-media-gay/new-york-times-under-fire-for-homophobic-cartoon-of-trump-and-putin-idUSKBN1K802J |agency=Reuters |date=July 18, 2018}}</ref>
==Hiring of Sarah Jeong== In August 2018, ''The New York Times'' hired [[Sarah Jeong]] to join its editorial board as lead writer on technology, commencing in September.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytco.com/sarah-jeong-joins-the-timess-editorial-board/ | title=Sarah Jeong Joins The Times’s Editorial Board | date=August 1, 2018 | accessdate = August 2, 2018 | publisher = New York Times Company}}</ref> The hiring sparked a strongly negative reaction in conservative media, which highlighted derogatory [[Twitter|tweets]] about [[white people]] that Jeong had posted mostly in 2013 and 2014.<ref name=AP>{{cite news |title=NY Times stands by new hire Sarah Jeong over Twitter furor |url=https://www.apnews.com/519ffe9de59149639cfbca3a6cefd72a |agency=Associated Press |date=August 2, 2018}}</ref><ref name=bbc>{{cite news |title=NY Times stands by 'racist tweets' reporter |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-45052534 |work=BBC News |date=August 2, 2018}}</ref> Critics characterized her tweets as being racist; Jeong said that the posts were "counter-[[trolling]]" in reaction to [[harassment]] she had experienced, and that she regretted adopting this tactic.<ref name=AP /> The ''Times'' stated that it had reviewed her social media history before hiring her, and that it did not condone the posts.<ref name=AP /><ref name=bbc />
==See also== *[[Media bias]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *''[https://www.nytimes.com/ The New York Times on the Web]'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070612001825/http://www.nytco.com/company-timeline-1851.html Official history of the Times] *[[Jacob Sullum|Sullum, Jacob]] (2010-04-28) [http://reason.com/archives/2010/04/28/free-speech-for-us Free Speech for Us: The Gray Lady’s inconsistent defense of the First Amendment], ''[[Reason Magazine|Reason]]''
{{NY Times}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Criticism Of The New York Times}} [[Category:The New York Times]] [[Category:Journalism controversies by media organ|New York Times]]

{{Infobox video game | title = Toren | image = Toren_game.jpg | developer = Swordtales | designer = Alessandro Martinello | composer = Vinicius Kleinsorgen
Lucas Flicky | platforms = [[PlayStation 4]], [[Microsoft Windows]] | released = 12 May 2015 | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], [[Puzzle video game|puzzle]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''Toren''''' is a 2015 [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[puzzle video game]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[PlayStation 4]], developed by Swordtales and published by [[Versus Evil]].{{cite web |url=http://g1.globo.com/tecnologia/games/noticia/2015/04/game-brasileiro-toren-chega-em-12-de-maio-para-ps4-e-pc.html |title=Game brasileiro 'Toren' chega em 12 de maio para PS4 e PC}} Inspired by games such as ''[[Ico]]'', ''[[Shadow of the Colossus]]'' and ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'', ''Toren'' was the first game funded by Brazilian government's public tax credit, through [[Rouanet Law]].{{cite web |url=http://zh.clicrbs.com.br/rs/entretenimento/noticia/2015/05/primeiro-jogo-financiado-pela-lei-rouanet-gaucho-toren-sera-lancado-em-12-de-maio-4753549.html |title=Primeiro jogo financiado pela Lei Rouanet, gaúcho "Toren" será lançado em 12 de maio}} == Plot == In ''Toren'', the player controls the Moonchild, a girl born in a magic tower, and who has the goal to reach the top of it. The game begins with her as a baby; she grows up and develops as she goes up the tower's levels, solving puzzles and avoiding traps until defeating the dragon that lives at the top of the tower. Moonchild has visions about a wizard, her own origin and tower's nature. == Development == ''Toren'' ([[Dutch language|Dutch]] for "[[tower]]") started development in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://br.ign.com/brasil/3789/interview/superproducao-brasileira-game-toren-e-lancado-apos |title=Superprodução brasileira, game Toren é lançado após quatro anos de desenvolvimento}} Swordtales' staff pledged funding by the [[Rouanet Law]] in 2013, achieving [[Brazilian real|R$]]75 thousand.{{cite web |url=http://geracaogamer.com/2015/04/20/o-primeiro-game-aprovado-na-lei-rouanet-nao-foi-toren-mas-sim-game-comix/ |title=O primeiro game aprovado na Lei Rouanet não foi Toren, mas sim Game Comix}} The law began to award electronic game cultural projects in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/tec/2013/08/1324415-game-toren-levanta-r-40-mil-pela-lei-rouanet-meta-e-arrecadar-370-mil.shtml |title=Game "Toren" levanta R$ 75 mil pela Lei Rouanet; meta é arrecadar 370 mil - 12/08/2013 - Tec - Folha de S.Paulo |website=www1.folha.uol.com.br}} Total budget of the game was R$350,000, the rest of the money being funded by sponsors. == Reception == ''Toren'' was met with a mixed reception by the video game press. The ambiance "full of symbolism and mysticism" were praised but the game's problematic controls, camera angles and bugs were criticized.[http://overloadr.com.br/analises/2015/05/analise-toren/ «Análise - Toren»].[http://www.pcgamer.com/toren-reivew/ «Toren review»].[http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/toren-review/1900-6416133/ «Toren Review»].{{Video game reviews |na=true |PC=true |PS4=true |GSpot_PC=5/10[http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/toren-review/1900-6416133/] |Destruct_PC=6/10[https://www.destructoid.com/review-toren-291711.phtml] |IGN_PC=6.5/10 [http://br.ign.com/toren-swordtales/3985/review/review-toren] |MC_PC=57/100 [http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/toren] |MC_PS4=56/100[http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/toren] |GR_PC=62.87/100[http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/826298-toren/index.html] |GR_PS4=61.45/100[http://www.gamerankings.com/ps4/826297-toren/index.html] }} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://toren-game.com/ Official website] [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Action-adventure games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Brazil]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Windows games]] {{videogame-stub}}
